properties.Incident Description: El Paso Natural Gas Company pipeline ruptured and caused fire near campground and El Paso River. Twelve campers were killed and three vehicles destroyed.

Exxon Mobil natural gas liquids transmission pipeline was ruptured by a bulldozer, and spewed a cloud of liquid propane which ignited a fireball when a car driven by a police officer drove through it. The police officer died and one home was destroyed by the blaze.

properties.Incident Type: Drinking water well geyser and impairment
properties.Incident Description: Fracking began on three wells adjacent to the Amos family residence. Very same day, geyser erupts from the family water well, flooding a pasture with contaminated, fizzing water. Henceforth, their drinking water has been methane-contaminated and filled with sediment.
El Paso Natural Gas Company pipeline failed, releasing gas for an hour before igniting.
Chevron natural gas pipeline damaged by a backhoe. Trailer home damaged by explosion and 125 people evacuated.
Mid Louisiana Gas Pipeline company pipeline ruptured, discharging  15,000 gallons of natural gas into a small unnamed tributary of the Black Bayou.
El Paso Natural Gas Company pipeline ruptured, causing a fire which burned an area 600 feet in diameter. Three people were evacuated from three homes.
Williams Company natural gas pipeline failed, causing a "significant" explosion. Nearby school, grocery store, and homes within a 4-mile radius were evacuated.
Natural gas collected in the basement of the Harper residence, which is near several gas wells. When the furnace came on, the house exploded, killing the Harper couple and their grandson.

Concerned citizens discover gas bubbling up in the West Divide Creek; water inspection reveals contamination of the creek and nearby ponds by benzene, toluene, and xylene, indicating that the methane contamination of the groundwater was due to Encana's local fracking operation. Encana later fined for its failure to properly cement frack wells, resulting in the leakage and contamination.
Methane seepage from nearby fracking well filled the home of the Harper family. The house exploded, killing both Harpers and their grandson.
Natural gas blowout, contaminating two aquifers, groundwater, and drinking with benzene and other contaminants. Dozens of families were evacuated.

The Bounds' pump house in rural Huerfano County, proximate to 50 fracking sites, exploded after methane seeped into their water well. Their water was found to be highly methane contaminated, warranting several separate evacuations.
Kushequa community water well exploded after natural gas from nearby frack well seeped inside.
Families ordered to evacuate homes after gas found to be at explosive levels after contractor drilled new natural gas wells in the vicinity. Families able to return to their homes on 12/28.

A home exploded in Bainbridge, a small town suburb of Cleveland. Methane entered several water wells and the basement of the house, causing the explosion. Later found that a fracking well's faulty casing caused the gas to enter the aquifer. Contaminated dozens of wells and resulted in a 43-household class action suit.

Waste containment pit on a mesa overlooking the town of Parachute leaked 1.6 million gallons, including fracking fluid. Seeped into groundwater and into the Parachute Creek, tributary to the Colorado River.
Local spring found to be contaminated as a result of fracking, after local residents, the Prathers, discovered their tap water to be contaminated with carcinogenic BTEX solution, used in fracking.
Resident, Ned Prather, hospitalized after drinking his tap water which had been contaminated because of nearby fracking operations. Water found to contain benzene.
Off-road diesel spilled from a Cabot fuel line and pooled in a flooded wetland.
A truck driver working to create an access road spilled a 1,000 gallon tank of off-road diesel, requiring a total excavation of 272 tons of contaminated soil.
Fracking drilling pad caught fire, and rig burned throughout the day.
A pipeline in the Transco pipeline system, operated by Williams Gas Pipeline, ruptured and exploded. Five people were injured, five homes levelled, and 100 other houses damaged.
A Dominion fracking well exploded into flames, burning for eleven days before special firefighters called up from Texas were able to put out the fire.
Drilling mud found to be leaking from Cabot's Black 2H Well site from an unlined trench.

properties.Incident Type: Water well dries up, returns contaminated.
properties.Incident Description: Drinking water well at residence near fracking site goes dry; returning five days later, it has become contamianted, unpleasant in taste and smell, salty, and bubbling with methane. At least two households have been found to contain dangerous levels of gas. The contamination issues have all been linked to the fracking.

Monongahela River found to be exceeding state water quality levels regarding total dissolved solids ("unusually high"). Problem traced to influx of fracking wastewater to sewage plants discharging into the river.

Pollution of fresh groundwater with methane by Cabot Oil & Gas caused one residence's backyard well to explode. The drinking water of nine homes had been contaminated with a threat of explosion in four of them.
Cabot spilled approx. 100 gallons of diesel fuel oil at their Gesford 3 Well site.
On a Chesapeake Chancellor fracking site, a tank leaked 295 gallons of 36% hydrochloric acid solution. 126 tons of contaminated soil had to be excavated.

Drilling mud found to be leaking into the ground at the B Severcool 1 Well site where the drilling mud pump had sprung a leak. Estimated that 25-60 barrels of the mud had flowed into ditches around the site and in an adjacent field.
Several thousands of gallons spilled from Chesapeake site; never tested for potentially dangerous minerals or salts.
Leak of drilling mud at Cabot's Gesford 1 Well Site. Mud had flowed off the drill site into the Burdick Creek.
Acid spill of 420 gallons from Chesapeake's Van Noy well site. A private pond was contaminated, along with a swath of trees and vegetation.
Fugitive gas discovered in water well, combustible gas in another, believed to come from a recently drilled gas well on adjacent property.
Cattle ingested fracking fluid in a pasture adjacent to a Chesapeake fracking site; 19 died.
Beginning of spate of small earthquakes, the first ever recorded in Cleburne's history. Fracking is believed to be the cause behind the sudden and unprecedented seismicity.
Over 30,000 gallons of diluted wastewater overran an East Resources Inc. waste pit and soaked into a pasture.

A worker for Fortuna Energy/Talisman Energy drove a tanker leaking hydrochloric acid over public roads between well sites in the Troy Township. The tanker leaked 100-200 gallons of acid, contaminating soils.
Natural gas leak from an East Resources Oriskany well confirmed. Methane impacted drinking water wells, tributaries to Lycoming Creek, forced evacuation of one home and closure of access roads.

Monongahela River found to be exceeding state water quality levels regarding total dissolved solids ("unusually high"). Problem traced to influx of fracking wastewater to sewage plants discharging into the river.
Tapo Energy spill into Buckeye Creek.
Over the course of the day, nearly 7000 gallons of toxic fracking materials were spilled, entering the local Stevens Creek.
Third spill at Cabot's Heitsman well in Susquehanna County. Stevens Creek and local wetland impacted.

Range Resources spilled 250 barrels of frack fluid from a transmission line into a high-quality, specially-protected waterway, killing fish and other aquatic life. Over 250 barrles of frack fluid entered a tributary of the Brush Run.
A leaky tank storing water and fracking chemicals released about 7,980 gallons, most of which was absorbed into the ground, contaminating a tributary to the Alex Branch.

Monongahela River found to be exceeding state water quality levels regarding total dissolved solids ("unusually high"). Problem traced to influx of fracking wastewater to sewage plants discharging into the river.
A Chesapeake Energy gas well blowout caused the evacuation of 2 neighborhoods, killing one worker and injuring another.
A 750,000-gal wastewater pit (Atlas Resources) overflowed into tributary within a high-quality watershed

Spill of 110 gallons of drilling muds; Chief Oil and Gas disputed the fact that the muds were synthetic and chemically altered, though inspector noted that the mud - "Hydraul-EZ" - listed several chemical ingredients, some proprietary.

Between 3,000 and 6,000 gallons of synthetic mud were spilled into a wetland during the boring of a pipeline for drilling company Chief Oil and Gas. Barriers at bank of nearby stream were not successful at preventing the mud from breaching the stream.
Large diesel fuel spill off of Talisman's natural gas well pad. Spill went off of well pad and into adjacent farm field.
(2010) Airform HD, fracking chemical, discharged into the Pine Creek from a drilling site run by Pennsylvania General Energy.
Anadarko spilled 8,000-12,000 gallons of synthetic mud at their drilling site in the State Forest.
Condensate on an Atlas Resources wastewater pit caught fire, engulfing the pit and its plastic liner, creating a plume of black smoke visible miles off.

properties.Incident Type: Well blowout; spill at well site
properties.Incident Description: A natural gas blowout at a site operated by Exco Resources caused hundreds of people to be evacuated from their homes in the area, and also contaminated the drinking water aquifer, making it unsafe for most uses including consumption.
28 cows quarantined after drinking from a pool of leaked waste water which formed on a farm adjacent to an East Resource Inc drilling site.
Blowout of EOG Resource frack well which, according to DEP secretary, narrowly avoided being a "catastrophic incident."
Chief Oil & Gas well exploded when a pocket of methane gas was hit during drilling. 7 workers were hospitalized.

Owners of dairy farm where Chief Oil & Gas fracking well is located first notice a spill of hyraulic oil on their property; take 5 months for Chief to adequately deal with and clean up the spill. Later discovered that Chief intentionally buried the spill.
Anadarko spilled 150 barrels of frack fluid at its drilling site.
DEP quarantines 28 head of cattle which came into contact with wastewater from nearby fracking operation, in order to protect the public from the contaminated beef.
Fire broke out at Chesapeake well site. Burned for 2 hours; no injuries.
Gas well owned by Huntley & Huntley exploded, killing two workers; ensuing fire burned for hours.

Chief Gathering LLC illegally discharges hydrostatic testing water, comingled with an unknown industrial waste, into the Big Run watershed; after first notifiying the DEP that said discharge would not occur.
Water available to Pavilion residents grows so contaminated that ATSDR recommends that alternative water sources used for consumption, showering, and other uses.
Blowout on natural gas platform, causing leakage of nearly 250 barrels of oil and 2,000 barrels of frack water.
XTO Energy leaked 50,000 gallons of wastewater from an unsecured well site. It polluted a tributary to the Sugar Run and tainted two drinking water wells.
Leak of500 barrels of flowback water at Rockwater Energy Solution fracking site

properties.Incident Type: Well blowout; spill at well site
properties.Incident Description: Blowout of one of Talisman Energy's frack wells, causing uncontrolled discharge of frack fluids into the State Forest.
Fracking well caught fire at a Williams well.
A truck hauling waste water from an Anadarko drill site rolled over on a rural road.
Leak detected at fracking site, causing spill in a localized area, forcing a shutdown of operations at the site.
3,400 gallons of treated fracking flowback water were spilled on the Pike after a truck crash involving the fluid's carrier.
Flash fire during well testing involving 5 storage tanks. Three workers injured in the blaze, one critically.
Tank of compressor station caught fire, causing the hatch of another tank to blow off.
Natural gas drilling rig caught fire at corner of state park, causing a small wildfire.

properties.Incident Type: Well blowout; spill at well site
properties.Incident Description: Chesapeake gas well blew out during fracturing, spewing water and unidentified chemicals for 12 hours.

At least 12,600 gallons of brine leaked into a vegetated field along Petro Harvester Company's saltwater disposal pipelines. The leak was later found to have been occuring for weeks prior to discovery, leaking closer to 2 million gallons of brine and sterilizing dozens of acres of land.
900 gallons of drilling mud was spilled into the creek by the Laser Notheast Gathering Company.
500 gallons of drilling mud was spilled into the creek by the Laser Notheast Gathering Company.
No more than 100 gallons of drilling mud was spilled into the creek by the Laser Notheast Gathering Company.
Production unit at an Anadarko gas well site exploded due to a malfunction.
Range Resource spilled 400 barrels of treated frack fluid from a frack well.

Massive wastewater injection by fracking companies New Dominion LLC and Spess Oil caused swarm of earthquakes, including a 5.7 magnitude quake which injured 2 people and damaged more than 200 homes and businesses.
Tennessee Gas Pipeline natural gas line exploded, creating a 30-foot-wide crater, setting three houses and two barns on fire (one home destroyed), and causing minor injuries to residents.
Chesapeake/Nomac drilling rig drilled into a shallow gas pocket, causing an explosion and a fire that burnt the well to the ground.
Spill of 8,200 gal of brine, 89 gal of diesel fuel by PGE

An explosion and fire at a fracking well injured three workers. The fire burned for several hours before it was extinguished, and was caused by the explosion of an oil tank. The site was a fracking wastewater storage site.
An explosion occurred in Williams Partners LP's Lathrop compressor station, blowing a hole in the engine-holding building complex, shaking homes up to a half-mile away from the scene of the blast.
Fiery explosion at a Vann Energy location, leaving two workers injured. Nearby homes were evacuated.

Michael Leighton, homeowner, found his water well bubbling with methane, 80 feet up to the top of the well. The DEP found his basement to have high levels of methane, warranting an evacuation notice. Cause is believed to be a botched repair job at a nearby Chesapeake fracking well.

Geyser shooting methane-infused water on Ralston Hunting Club property, in the middle of a State Forest, began erupting, because of nearby Shell Cochran well pad. Shell and the DEP issued an evacuation notice for the surrounding area.
Methane leak from fracking site caused evacuation of nearby residents, and geyser-like overflow of drinking water well.
An explosion occurred at a BP compressor station for fracked gas, killing one and injuring two others.
Spill of 4700 gallons of hydrochloric acid at Chief Oil & Gas well pad

Range Resources spill of 3,066 gal of brine at well pad at Cornwall Mtn. Hunting Club. Contaminated the high-quality Trout Run, and failed to remediate the damage for a year. 1,294 tons of contamianted soil were removed.
Halliburton truck carrying 4,000 gallons of hydrochloric acid drove through town leaking its load, thus forming a toxic gaseous cloud of the chemical.
Explosion of Encana Corp. fracking well, killing one worker, Brian Wallace, and injuring three others.
Valve fire at a Chief Oil & Gas well site; one separator unit also caught fire.
Mud, clay, and sediment were released into the creek when during work for a pipeline project. Inergy Midstream LP was constructing the pipeline through the creek.

Truck hauling 7 tons of residual fracking waste water spilled into the Pine Creek after crashing into a rock wall. The truck was driven by Minuteman Environmental Services and was carrying 4,600 gallons of fracking waste.

Between Nov. 21, 2012, and Jan. 31, 2013, Hardrock Excavating, fracking waste transport/disposal company owned by Ben Lupo, illegally dumped fracking waste into a tributary of the Mahoning River on at least 20 separate occasions. OH EPA testified that because of the damage wreacked by the discharges of fracking waste, aquatic life had been utterly wiped out.

Over a period of 4 days from Nov. 12 to Nov. 16 XTO Energy Inc. illegally disposed of toxic wastewater at a site lacking the proper equipment to handle the substance. More than 93,000 gallons were illegally stored at the site, of which 57,000 gallons were unaccounted for following a spill from a storage tank. The waste polluted a tributary of Sugar Run.
Fireball explosion of a natural gas transmission pipeline; melted four lanes of highway I-77, flattened 4 homes and damaged 5 others before being put out four hours later.
Fire broke out a Devon Energy site where a natural gas well was being drilled. Evacuation order issued for residences within a half mile radius due to concerns about harmful gas.
Approximately 42 barrels of frack fluid were spilled at the Rex/McElhinney well.

Oily, "green-tinted" fracking fluid leaked from a PDC fracking well for approximately a day and a half before workers were able to close the leaking valve. The leak caused a strong odor of petroleum in a 1,000 foot radius of the drilling site, residents reported, in addition to oil-laced mist blowing towards their homes.
Spill of 40 barrels of recycled water.
Blowout at gas well sent frack fluid, chemicals into Bradford County creek. Chesapeake Energy was operating the well which had the incident, blaming equipment failures for the blowout and spillage.
Explosion at natural gas production site caused death of one worker.

100,000 gallons (95,000 gal drilling waste + 5,000 gal water) leaked from a waste containment pit, most flowing downhill into a nearby creek, a tributary of Big Wheeling Creek, which feeds into Ohio River.
Methane and hydrocarbons accicentally emitted over period of 3 hours at Spectra compressor station.
Thousands of gallons of fracking waste escaped from a malfunctioning fracking well, causing 3 nearby families to be evacuated from their homes.

Fracking fluid spill at well pad of Carrizo Gas Company. Drill malfunction caused thousands of gallons to spurt out (800 gal/minute at one point), prompting fears of an explosion. Seven families were evacuated. Spill mostly contained; some got onto roadway.
Dominion gas well exploded, sending flames upwards of 30'; was visible for three miles around. Several trees were knocked down by the blast.

DCP Midstream natural gas compressor station had explosion, causing fire which was visible from milies away, which caused trees, shed and car to become ablaze as well. Homes within a square mile were evacuated.
An explosion at Eureka Hunter Pipeline's operating station caused fatal injuries for two facility workers.

After faulty valve came off of Atlas Energy natural gas pipeline near Route 219, oil and gas shot out of the pipe as high as 60' in the air, being blown across the highway by wind and causing slippery conditions. The spill lasted about 3 hours.

After faulty hose broke loose from storage tank, 9,000 gallons of flowback fluid spilled from Carrizo Oil & Gas site, flowing into a garage across the road, a miniature horse farm, and a farmhouse basement.
Explosion and fire at Williams natural gas compressor station, starting in one of three compressors.
Gulfport fracking waste was illegally dumped by Harch Environmental Resources down a hillside, into a private pond.
An explosion at a natural gas pipeline plant, the Williams Gas Pipeline Facility, injured 13.
Explosion at Williams Gas Pipeline facility, 13 injured.

Wellbore drilling by PDC Energy created "silty and muddy" condition in White Day Creek after pressurized drilling method "broke free." DEP issued notice of violation to PDC for creating conditions prohibited in state waters, and not taking measures adequate to preventing a spill.
Columbia Natural Gas pipelne which runs under the Ohio River ruptured early Thursday morning, spewing gas out of the water for several hours before CNG employees arrived at noon.
Energy Transfer natural gas pipeline ruptured, sparking explosion and fire.
Methane in a tank holding flowback fluid exploded, causing a fire which severely burned 5 workers, 2 of whom later died from their injuries.
Explosion at Ruddy Alt Pad operated by Antero Resources; five workers suffered burn injuries of varying severity.
Portion of county road collapsed, settling 3-4 feet, after drilling operations commenced in the vicinity underneath it.
Spill of brine and produced water at Inflection Energy Inc.'s well site.
At saltwater disposal site at oilfield, two workers were attempting to fix valve on leaking disposal system when they were overcome by escaping hydrogen sulfide fumes.

Natural gas leak on Gulf of Mexico left 4-mile-wide "rainbow sheen" on water's surface, according to Coast Guard. Talos Energy, responsible for the well, was attempting to plug it when leak occurred. Leak potentially toxic to marine life.
Diesel spill at Penneco Oil Co. Inc. well site caused vegetation death and leached into the Claylick Run.
Fire broke out at Stone Energy gas well pad in the evening.
Flaring incident at the MarkWest natural gas processing plant, caused by malfunctioning de-ethanizer.
Energy Corporation of America caught discharging industrial waste into waters within Moshannon State Forest without a permit.
Halliburton tanker carrying diluted hydrochloric acid leaked while traveling on Interstate 70, causing the highway to be shut down for four hours.
Rupture of natural gas pipeline connecting compressor station and gas well. Originally thought an explosion, prompting an evacuation order.
Out-of-control natural gas well on Gulf of Mexico caught fire, after a blowout 44 hours before. Contractors hired to contain the well and extinguish it were unable to get closer than 200 feet.
Bridgeport Tanker Truck was having a hatch welded onto it when it exploded, presumably from escaping vapors. Worker doing the welding was killed.
Slurry from pipeline leaked into a tributary to the Muskingum River.
Oil spill at Chief Oil & Gas well pad due to tank valve being left open and hole in container. 84 gallons of mineral oil impacted ground surface.
Rockwater Energy Solutions truck carrying ethylene glycol solution to well site crashed, spilling 265 of the lubricant onto a field.
Spill of produced water at well pad, due to holes in container/coil tubing unit.
Natural gas pipeline exploded underground, causing a cornfield to go up in flames. 300' high flames were visible for 20 miles around. 80 families were evacuated.
MarkWest pipeline spilled an unknown but potentially explosive liquid into a stream after it was damaged by a landslide.
Longhorn steer killed after coming into contact with hydrogen sulfide gas from pipeline on natural gas & oil facility adjacent to his pasture.
Spark at fracking rig ignited a fireball which burned on the rig for an hour and sent three workers to the hospital.
Natural gas pipeline exploded, sending flames 200' up, barn damaged.
Fish kill caused after MarkWest natural gas pipeline ruptured and leaked into state waters.
Flaring incident at the MarkWest natural gas processing plant. Black smoke visible from the plant; locals experienced burning eyes, burning throat, nausea.
Storage tank ruptured, spilling 5000 gallons of 12% sulfuric acid solution into drainage ditch and tributary of Shenango River. Dead fish found in tributary.
Fracking wastewater pond overflowed and flooded local residents' property.
Whitaker Enterprises tanker truck discovered dumping brine onto roadway; liquids breached the Clearfork Creek.
Nabors drilling rig exploded after horizontal drilling into Eagle Ford Shale, causing a local evacuation.
Chevron pipeline leaks unknown quantity of natural gas into Gulf of Mexico near Pascagoula, MS.
Tesoro Co. pipeline rupture, spilling 20,600 barrels of oil over an area the size of seven football fields.
7-barrel oil spill.
500-barrel crude oil spill by Hiland Partners LP at their transfer facility.
A fire broke out after a tank exploded at the Jonah Gas natural gas field operated by Encana; three workers were injured, including one who was airlifted to a hospital in critical condition.
Two tremors felt in Azle, within an uncharacteristic swarm of 20 around that same time. Deep-well injection of fracking waste blamed for the tremors.

Pressure valve blew off of compressor station, leading to 50-minute period in which 70,098 cubic feet of natural gas were released into the atmosphere. Residents were startled, describing the noise as akin to a jet plane taking off.
Hunt Oil Co. caught illegally dumping fracking fluid into a dirt road from a tanker truck.

Three earthquakes felt in Trinidad, four more throughout the month of January. The uncharacteristic intensity in magnitude of the seimisicity  is thought to be triggered by the deep injection of fracking wastewater.
Explosion and fire on a Chevron gas well pad. Two wells were on fire for two weeks before being put out. One worker was killed and one injured.

An underground natural gas pipeline exploded, creating a 50-foot-wide crater in the ground, causing three homes to catch on fire, two of which were destroyed, and sending two people to the hospital. Twenty homes were evacuated as a state of emergency was declared because of the incident.

Whiting Petroleum Corp. well became out of control and  was leaking frack fluid at a rate of 50-70 barrels a day. ""This is a large one and also a health and human risk, it's a big one," said Lynn Helms, head of ND's Dept. of Mineral Resources.
A gas tank exploded across the street from a wildlife refuge. Two acres of land were scorched and nearby residents reported that the explosion shook their houses. 80% of the facility was destroyed.
At least 200 garbage bags of radioactive oil socks found illegally dumped in an abandoned gas station.
properties.Notes: Specific date of discovery hard to pin down - I think it's 3/3, but double check.

properties.Incident Description: A flash fire broke out at a natural gas processing plant while workers were changing a component to filter the gas stream. 4 workers were injured.
Natural gas distribution pipeline was ruptured by workmen and subsequently exploded and caught fire. A nearby motel and store were evacuated.
Natural gas pipeline exploded near the intersection of two country roads, causing flames which reached dozens of feet upwards and burned for hours.
Hilland Crude pipeline rupture, spilling 34,000 gallons of oil.
Brine spill in Atlas Resource's containment facility, overflowing containment dike, flowing into access road and creating a vegetation kill.
Large explosion at a natural gas processing plant, injuring 4 workers and causing the evacuation of 400 residents; emitted mushroom cloud of black smoke visible a mile off.
650 barrels of oil and 450 barrels of brine spilled at Oasis Petroleum well site.
Natural gas worker found dead at Noble Energy pump station, believed to be from exposure to toxic gas.
Substance used to give natural gas its odor leaks from natural gas dehydration station, spreading stench.
Significant leak at Range Resource's John Day Impoundment, requiring removal of significant volume of contamianted soil.
Radioactive oil socks, used in fracking wastewater filtration, found illegally dumped on a trucking site north of Divide County. 20 garbage cans' full were located.
Explosion at Williams Partners LP natural gas processing plant, causing evacuation of town residents.
Natural gas explosion in an RKI Exploration & Production-operated oilfield. Two workers killed, nine injured.
A train carrying oil from the Bakken shale derailed, spilling 30,000 gallons (some into the James River), causing the evacuation of 300 people, and creating a 200-foot-high fireball.

100 barrels of drilling mud spilled from the well (PDC Energy of Colorado) and ran into nearby creek. Seven residents evacuated over fear of explosions due to leaking gas. Substance thought potentially harmful to the unnamed creek's wildlife.

Well being drilled in preparation for fracking began leaking, causing local residents to be evacuated. Drilling mud was being discharged at 10 gal/minute at one point; discharge breached local creek before it was contained. "Wet gas" also escaped.
Spill of 100 barrels of brine and 140 barrels of oil from Samson Resources site, affecting a nearby farm.
Seismic activity thought to be triggered by local wastewater injection. 3.4 magnitude earthquake felt on the 31st. Seismic activity is uncharacteristic for the area.

Seismic activity was triggered by local wastewater injection. Greeley felt a 2.3 magnitude quake; seismic activity is uncharacteristic for the area. NGL Water Solution DJ, the company doing the injecting, may have violated its permit by injecting more than the allowed volume of wastewater.
Natural gas pipeline operated by Enterprise Products exploded in a fireball, injuring one nearby driver.

properties.Incident Type: Well site explosion and fire, fish kill, drinking water contamination
properties.Incident Description: Explosive fire at the Eisenbarth well site, caused by malfunction in hydraulic tubing. 20 trucks caught fire. Roughly 20 familes had to be evacuated. Caused a chemical leak which lead to a significant fish kill (over 70,000) in a nearby stream which is also a drinking water source.

Discovery of a pipeline hemorrhage which is suspected to have begun around July 4. About 1 million gallons of fracking salt water have seeped into the ground of the reservation; suspected that some of this amount has breached a lake, Bear Den Bay, which is a tributary to a source of drinking water, Lake Sakakawea. Vegetation impacted and killed.
Noble Energy storage tank spilled 7,500 gallons of oil into the River after flooding damaged the tank.

500 barrels of acid -- over 20,000 gallons -- from a fracking site spilled into an alfalfa field, and the runoff has the potential to endanger the nearby Turkey Creek, which contributes to Hennessey's drinking water.
Vintage Production fracking company caught illegally dumping fracking waste near a drill site.
Talisman Energy spilled used frack fluids at its Klein gas well, polluting a small and untitled waterway. Between 4,200 and 6,300 gallons were spilled.

Spill of fracking fluids, including hydrochloric acid, into Acorn Fork Creek; ensuing fish kill caused death of many/most aquatic specimens in the creek, including members of an endangered species of fish. MONTH DESIGNATION UNCLEAR (May/June/spread over both.)
Fortuna Energy frack wells found discharging flowback fluids into a drainage ditch, sediment basin, and a tributary of the Sugar Creek.
Fugitive gas leak into bathroom of a residence, igniting and exploding (killing one) when a candle was lit.
